spotted_lanternfly.description: The spotted lanternfly is an invasive planthopper native to China, India, and Vietnam. It was first detected in Pennsylvania in 2014 and has since spread to multiple states.

identification.adult: Adults are approximately 1 inch long and 0.5 inches wide. Wings are gray with black spots when closed. When open, hindwings reveal red patches with black spots and white bands.
identification.nymph: Early nymphs (1st-3rd instar) are black with white spots. Late nymphs (4th instar) are red with black stripes and white spots.
identification.egg_mass: Egg masses appear as gray, mud-like coverings on smooth surfaces. Each mass contains 30-50 eggs arranged in rows.

host_plants: Tree of Heaven (Ailanthus altissima) - preferred host
spotted_lanternfly.damage: Spotted lanternflies feed on plant sap, weakening plants and causing oozing wounds. Their honeydew excretion promotes sooty mold growth, further harming plants and creating sticky messes on surfaces below.
spotted_lanternfly.spread: Can spread through egg masses on vehicles, outdoor equipment, firewood, and other materials. Adults can jump and fly short distances.

physical: Scrape egg masses into bags with alcohol or hand sanitizer
Use sticky bands on tree trunks (with barriers to protect wildlife)
Stomp adults and nymphs when spotted
Remove Tree of Heaven where appropriate
chemical: Apply EPA-approved insecticides during appropriate life stages
prevention: Inspect vehicles and equipment before traveling
Check outdoor items for egg masses in fall and winter
Report sightings to state agricultural departments

spotted_lanternfly.lifecycle: One generation per year. Eggs overwinter and hatch in spring (April-July). Nymphs develop through 4 instars from May-July. Adults emerge July-December and lay eggs September-November.
spotted_lanternfly.economic_impact: Threatens agricultural industries including grapes, apples, hops, and hardwood timber. Pennsylvania losses estimated at $324 million annually if uncontrolled.

white_tailed_deer.description: While native to North America, white-tailed deer populations have become overabundant in many areas due to lack of natural predators and habitat changes, causing them to function as invasive species in certain contexts.

identification.size: Adults weigh 100-300 pounds. Height 3-4 feet at shoulder.
identification.appearance: Reddish-brown coat in summer, grayish-brown in winter. White underside of tail raised when alarmed. Males (bucks) grow antlers.

problems_caused: Vehicle collisions causing human injuries and fatalities
Transmission of tick-borne diseases (Lyme disease vectors)
Competition with native species for resources

exclusion: Use electric fencing for larger areas
Individual tree protection with wire cages
repellents: Commercial deer repellent sprays (need regular reapplication)
landscaping: Create barriers with thorny or strongly scented plants
population_control: Sharpshooting by professionals in urban areas

white_tailed_deer.ecological_impact: Overabundant deer populations prevent forest regeneration by consuming tree seedlings, alter plant community composition, and reduce habitat quality for ground-nesting birds and other wildlife.
white_tailed_deer.population_trends: Estimated 30+ million white-tailed deer in the US, compared to fewer than 500,000 in the early 1900s. Populations have exploded due to elimination of predators (wolves, cougars) and game management practices.

general_tips.reporting: Always report invasive species sightings to your state's Department of Agriculture or Natural Resources. Early detection is crucial for control.
general_tips.prevention: The best defense against invasive species is prevention. Inspect outdoor items, don't move firewood, clean equipment between sites, and learn to identify local invasives.
general_tips.native_alternatives: When landscaping, choose native plants that support local ecosystems and are naturally resistant to local pests.
general_tips.community_action: Join local invasive species task forces, participate in removal events, and educate neighbors about identification and control.

faqs.question: Why are invasive species a problem?
faqs.answer: Invasive species harm native ecosystems by outcompeting native species, disrupting food chains, spreading diseases, and causing economic damage to agriculture and infrastructure. They often lack natural predators in their new environment, allowing populations to explode.

faqs.question: Should I kill spotted lanternflies if I see them?
faqs.answer: Yes. If you see a spotted lanternfly, you should kill it. Stomp adults and nymphs, and scrape egg masses into a bag with alcohol or hand sanitizer. Then report your sighting to your state agriculture department.

faqs.question: Can I get in trouble for killing spotted lanternflies?
faqs.answer: No. In affected states, residents are actually encouraged to kill spotted lanternflies on sight. There are no protections for this invasive pest.

faqs.question: Are deer really invasive?
faqs.answer: White-tailed deer are native to North America, but overabundant populations can cause invasive-like problems in many areas. Without natural predators and with abundant food sources, their populations have grown far beyond historical levels, causing significant ecological and economic damage.

faqs.question: What's the most important thing I can do about invasive species?
faqs.answer: Learn to identify invasive species in your area, report sightings early, and help prevent spread by not moving firewood, cleaning equipment, and checking vehicles for egg masses or hitchhiking pests before traveling.

faqs.question: When is spotted lanternfly season?
faqs.answer: Spotted lanternflies are visible from spring through late fall. Eggs hatch April-July, nymphs develop May-July, and adults are present July-December. Egg masses can be found and destroyed throughout winter.

faqs.question: Will spotted lanternflies harm humans or pets?
faqs.answer: No. Spotted lanternflies do not bite, sting, or harm humans or pets. They are primarily a threat to plants and agriculture.

faqs.question: How do I remove Tree of Heaven?
faqs.answer: Tree of Heaven is the preferred host for spotted lanternflies. Removal requires cutting and treating stumps with herbicide, as they resprout vigorously. Some areas recommend leaving a few trees as 'trap trees' treated with insecticide. Check local guidance before removal.
